podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The following is a conversation with Elon Musk, DJ, Matthew McDougall, Bliss Chapman, and Nolan Arbaugh about Neuralink and the future of humanity. DJ, Matthew, and Bliss are part of the incredible Neuralink team, while Nolan is the first human to have a Neuralink device implanted in his brain. I speak with each of them individually, so feel free to use the timestamps to jump around, or as I recommend, listen to the entire episode. This is the longest podcast I've ever done—it's a fascinating, technical, and wide-ranging conversation, and I loved every minute of it. Now, dear friends, here’s Elon Musk, his fifth time on The Lex Fridman Podcast, drinking water. I'm so over-caffeinated right now!

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Do you want some caffeine? I mean, sure. There's a Nitro drink that's supposed to keep you up until tomorrow afternoon, basically. So, what is Nitro? It's just got a lot of caffeine, or something? Don't ask questions; it's called Nitro. Do you need to know anything else? It's got nitrogen in it. That's ridiculous! I mean, what we breathe is 78% nitrogen anyway. Why do you need to add more? Most people think they're breathing oxygen, but they're actually breathing 78% nitrogen. You need a Milk Bar, like from "A Clockwork Orange." Is that a top three Kubrick film for you? "A Clockwork Orange" is pretty good.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
It's a significant and historic step for Neuralink to have successfully implanted a link into a human. Congratulations on that achievement! We also have a second implant underway. So far, it looks good; we have about 400 electrodes providing signals. 

As for scaling the number of human participants, it largely depends on the rate of regulatory approvals. We're hoping to have a total of 10 participants by the end of this year, which means we need to complete eight more.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
With each iteration, you'll learn a lot about the neurobiology of the brain and the entire Neuralink process, including decoding and signal processing. I believe it will improve significantly with each version. I don't want to jinx it, but the second implant has gone extremely well, with a lot of signals and electrodes functioning effectively. 

What improvements do you anticipate for Neuralink in the coming years? If we look ahead, the advancements will be substantial. We plan to dramatically increase the number of electrodes and enhance signal processing.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Even with only about 10 to 15% of the electrodes working with Noland, our first patient achieved a bits per second rate that is twice the world record. I believe we will vastly exceed the current world record by orders of magnitude in the coming years. In five years, we might reach 100 bits per second, or even a megabit, which would be faster than any human could communicate by typing or speaking. The bits per second (BPS) metric is interesting; there may be a significant leap in experience once we reach a certain level of BPS. This could unlock entirely new ways of interacting with computers and with other humans.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Other humans provided they have one and a link too, right? Otherwise, they won't be able to process all the signals fast enough. Do you think that'll improve the quality of intellectual discourse? 

Well, you could think about it this way: if you were to slow down communication, how would you feel about that? If you could only talk at, let's say, one-tenth of normal speed, it would feel agonizingly slow. Now, imagine if you could communicate clearly at 10, 100, or even 1,000 times faster than normal. 

I'm pretty sure nobody in their right mind listens to me at 1X; they listen at 2X. I can only imagine what 10X would feel like, or if I could actually understand it. I usually default to 1.5X. You can do 2X, but...

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: If I'm listening to something to help me sleep, I usually set it to 1.5x speed for 15 to 20-minute segments. If I'm paying attention, I'll increase it to 2x. However, once you get used to listening at 1.5x, regular speed feels painfully slow. I'm hesitant to switch back to 1x because I'm worried about becoming bored with how slowly people speak in the real world. It really depends on the person; some can communicate very quickly. Additionally, having a larger vocabulary can increase your effective bit rate in communication.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: That's a good way to put it. The effective bit rate raises the question of how much information is actually compressed in the low bit transfer of language. If a single word can convey what would normally require ten simple words, then you've achieved a significant compression—perhaps 10x. Memes function similarly; they act as a form of data compression. You are simultaneously presented with a wide range of symbols that you can interpret, allowing you to grasp the meaning faster than if it were conveyed through words or a simple picture. Of course, you're referring to memes broadly, encompassing ideas.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
The idea structure resembles an idea template, allowing you to add incremental information to a pre-existing concept in someone's mind. When you add this information, you convey much more than just a few words; you communicate everything associated with that meme. 

Do you think there will be emergent leaps in capability as the number of electrodes increases? Is there a specific number where the human experience will be altered? While we don't know for sure, do you think it might be 10,000 or 100,000? Certainly, if you're operating at around 10,000 bits per second, that could have significant implications.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: That's vastly faster than any human can communicate right now. If you consider the average bits per second of a human, it is less than one bit per second over the course of a day. There are 86,400 seconds in a day, and you don't communicate 86,400 tokens in that time. Therefore, your best average is less than one bit per second over 24 hours. It's quite slow. Even if you're communicating very quickly, you still need to model the mindset of the person you're speaking to. You take the concept you're trying to convey, compress it into a small number of syllables, and then speak them.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I hope that the other person decompresses the information into a conceptual structure that closely aligns with what you have in mind. There is a lot of signal loss in that process, resulting in very lossy compression and decompression. Much of what your neurons do is distill concepts down to a small number of symbols, such as the syllables I’m speaking or keystrokes, depending on the context. This is a significant part of brain computation. There is an argument that this process can be healthy or helpful because, as you try to compress complex concepts, you are forced to distill the essence of what is being communicated.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: It's essential to focus on the key concepts rather than the fluff. In the process of compression, we distill information down to what matters most because we can only convey a few points. This approach is helpful. As our data rates increase, it's likely that we will become more verbose. For example, my first computer had 8K of RAM, which made every byte count. Now, computers have many gigabytes of RAM. Even a simple iPhone app that just says "Hello, World" can be several megabytes, filled with unnecessary elements. Nonetheless, we still prefer to have the advanced capabilities of modern computers.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: With more memory and compute, Neuralink's long-term aspiration is to improve AI-human symbiosis by increasing the bandwidth of communication. Even in the most benign scenario with AI, we must consider that the AI will get bored waiting for humans to communicate. If AI can communicate at terabits per second while humans communicate at bits per second, it’s akin to talking to a tree. This raises an interesting question for a superintelligent species: what use are humans? There is an argument that humans serve as a source of will or purpose.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The human mind consists of two main components: the primitive limbic elements, which are similar to those found in reptiles, and the cortex, which is responsible for thinking and planning. The cortex is much smarter than the limbic system, yet it largely serves the limbic system's needs, trying to keep it satisfied. The amount of mental effort people invest in seeking sexual encounters, often without the intention of procreation, is remarkable. This seemingly absurd act of sex involves the cortex dedicating significant resources to figuring out how to engage in it.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: About 90% of the distributed computing power of humanity is spent on trying to achieve pleasure, primarily for hedonistic purposes. Most sexual activity, especially among modern humans, is recreational rather than for procreation. Your cortex, which is much smarter than your limbic system, attempts to satisfy the limbic system's desires, such as the need for sex or tasty food. This process is further augmented by a tertiary system, which includes devices like your phone, laptop, or iPad. So, you are already operating within this framework.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Cyborg, you have this tertiary compute layer in the form of your computer and all your applications. In the dating landscape, there's a massive amount of digital compute involved, like with Tinder and similar platforms. The compute that we humans have built is also participating. There are gigawatts of compute going into digital dating. 

What if AGI is happening as we speak? If we merge with AI, it will expand the compute that we humans use. That's certainly one aspect. However, the question remains: is there still a use for humans?

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: There's a fundamental question about the meaning of life: why do anything at all? If our limbic system provides a source of motivation, which then influences our cortex and higher cognitive functions, it might be that AI is simply trying to make the human limbic system happy. However, the will to act isn't solely about the limbic system; there are many complex factors involved. We also desire power, which is linked to the limbic system, but we also want to alleviate suffering in the world in a cooperative way. Not everyone shares this desire, but many people do. When humans come together, we start to develop this kind of collective motivation.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
The concept of collective intelligence is more complex in its will than the underlying individual descendants of apes. There are additional motivations that could serve as an interesting source of an objective function for AGI. For me, higher-level goals like understanding the meaning of life or the nature of the universe are of great interest, and I hope they are also of interest to AI. This aligns with the mission of XAI and GRO, which is to understand the universe. 

Do you think that when we have a neural link with 10,000 or 100,000 channels, most of the use cases will involve communication with AI?

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The systems are designed to address basic neurological issues, particularly for individuals with damaged neurons in their spinal cord or neck, as seen in our first two patients. The primary focus is on repairing fundamental neuron damage in these areas or in the brain itself. Our second product, called Blindside, aims to help individuals who are completely blind, whether due to damage to both eyes or the optic nerve, regain the ability to see by directly stimulating the neurons in the visual cortex. We are starting with these foundational challenges.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The basic issues to address include solving neuron damage, which could potentially help with conditions like schizophrenia and seizures. It may also aid in improving memory. There is a progression, much like a tech tree; for example, you need literacy before you can appreciate something complex like "Lord of the Rings." First, you need an alphabet and words, and then you can develop sagas. While there may be concerns for the future, the initial steps are crucial.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Years are primarily focused on addressing basic neurological damage, particularly for individuals with complete or near-complete loss of communication from the brain to the body. Stephen Hawking serves as an example. Neuralink could have a profound impact; imagine if Stephen Hawking could communicate as quickly as we are now, or even faster. This is not only possible but likely. There are two tracks to consider: medical and non-medical applications. Everything discussed could also be applied to non-disabled individuals in the future. The logical and sensible approach is to begin by addressing basic neuron damage issues.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: There is obviously some risk with the new device; you can't reduce the risk to zero. Therefore, you want to achieve the highest possible reward given that there is a certain irreducible risk. If someone experiences a significant improvement in their communication, that improvement is worth the risk. As the risk decreases, and if thousands of people have been using the device for years with minimal risk, then you might consider aiming for augmentation. Currently, we are actually planning to aim for augmentation in individuals with neuron damage.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: We aim to provide individuals with quadriplegia or complete loss of connection between the brain and body a communication data rate that exceeds that of normal humans. If we're capable of this, why not give people superpowers? The same applies to vision restoration; while the initial restoration may be low resolution due to the limitation of neurons that can be implanted and triggered, there are ways to enhance the experience. For instance, even with 10,000 neurons, it’s not limited to just 10,000 pixels because you can adjust the electric field.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
The field between the neurons can be organized in patterns. For example, having 10,000 electrodes could provide a resolution similar to a megapixel or 10 megapixels. Over time, this could lead to a resolution higher than that of the human eye, and you could also see in different wavelengths. It’s like Jord LeFleur from Star Trek; you could switch to radar, ultraviolet, infrared, or even eagle vision, depending on what you want to see. 

Let me ask you a question, similar to something Joe Rogan might ask: Do you think there will be advancements in this area? I recently took an interest in this topic. Have you ever tried it?

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Bro, I love you, Joe. Okay, wait, have you said much about it? I haven't. Well, spill the beans! It was truly incredible. The tables turned, didn't they? Wow, I mean, you're in the jungle, amongst the trees, with the shaman and the insects, surrounded by animals as far as I can see. That's the way to do it! Things are going to look pretty wild. I took an extremely high dose. Just don't go hugging an anaconda or something! You haven't lived until you've made love to an anaconda. I'm sorry, but Snakes and Ladders... yeah, it was intense.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I took a high dose of nine cups, which sounds like a lot. Usually, I start with one cup, but I jumped right in and took two on the first day. It was quite an experience, but not a revelation; it felt more like a little airplane ride. I saw some trees and visuals, including a dragon, but it wasn't deep space. With nine cups, I think I would have gone to Pluto or even deeper. One interesting aspect of my experience was that I expected to confront some demons or issues to work through.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: That's what everyone says. I had all positive experiences; I had just a pure soul. I kept thinking about it, and it had extremely high resolution. I reflected on the people in my life, and you were there. It wasn't just about my relationship with that person, but about them as individuals. I felt a deep gratitude for who they are. It was like an exploration, similar to watching characters in a game like Sims. I got to observe people and be in awe of how amazing they are. It sounds awesome, right? I was just waiting for when the demon would come. Maybe I'll have some insights then.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I felt extreme gratitude for the people I know, who seemed to have a glow about them. As I flew out from them, I could see Earth, our solar system, and our galaxy. That light, that glow, extended all across the universe. I traveled beyond the Milky Way and saw a vast number of galaxies. It was truly intergalactic.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I couldn't control my travel because I wanted to explore nearby distances in the solar system to see if there were aliens or anything like that. I didn't know about the implications of aliens, but I noticed glowing entities similar to how humans glow. This life force that I observed in humans seemed to be present throughout the universe as glowing dots. It made me feel like there was something remarkable, whatever makes humans amazing, all across the universe. It was incredible—no demons. I looked for demons, but there were none. Instead, I found dragons, which were quite impressive.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
There was nothing particularly scary, but there were dragons. They weren't frightening; they were friendly and protective. It was more like something out of Game of Thrones. The dragons were very large, and I was in a jungle at night, which can be intimidating. The trees began to look like dragons, and it felt like they were watching over me. 

The shaman and the others didn't speak English, which added to the unease, as we were worlds apart in many ways. They talked about the mother of the forest.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Protecting you is what I felt like. You're way out in the jungle; this is not like a tourist retreat, you know, like ten miles outside of a city. No, we went deep into the Amazon. A guy named Paul Rosley, who basically lives in the jungle like Tarzan, and I went on this adventure. 

So, can I get that same experience with Neuralink? Probably. That raises the question for non-disabled people: do you think there's a lot in our perception and experience of the world that could be explored or enhanced using Neuralink? Yes, I mean, Neuralink is really a generalized input-output device.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: It's about reading and generating electrical signals. Everything you've ever experienced—smells, emotions—are all electrical signals. It's strange to think that your entire life experience is distilled down to these signals from neurons, but that's what the evidence suggests. By triggering the right neuron, you can evoke a particular scent or make things glow. Essentially, you can think of the brain as a biological computer.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Chips or elements of a biological computer can address issues caused by brain damage, such as from a stroke. For instance, if a stroke affects your speech generation or your ability to move your left hand, Neuralink could potentially help. However, if you experience significant memory loss, we cannot retrieve those memories that are completely gone. We can restore your ability to form new memories, but not recover lost ones. That said, if part of the memory is still intact and the means of accessing it is impaired, we could potentially re-enable that access.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The ability to access memory can be compared to RAM in a computer. If the RAM or SD card is destroyed, you can't retrieve that data. However, if the connection to the SD card is damaged but fixable, then it can be repaired. With AI, we can repair photographs and fill in missing parts. Similarly, we could create the most probable set of memories based on all available information about a person. This would be a probabilistic restoration of memory. While this concept may seem esoteric, it highlights one of the most beautiful aspects of humanity.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Experience is about remembering good memories. As Danny Conan mentioned, we often live most of our lives in our memories rather than in the moment. We collect memories and relive them in our minds, and those are the good times. If we consider our entire lives, remembering the good times produces the greatest amount of happiness. Ultimately, what are we but our memories? What is death if not the loss of memory and information? 

Imagine a thought experiment: if you were disintegrated painlessly and then reintegrated a moment later...

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Teleportation, provided there's no information loss, makes the fact that your body was disintegrated irrelevant. Memories are a huge part of that; death is fundamentally the loss of information and memory. If we can store memories as accurately as possible, we essentially achieve a kind of immortality. 

You've discussed the threats and safety concerns of AI. Regarding long-term visions, do you think Neuralink is currently the best approach for AI safety? It's an idea that may help with AI safety, but I wouldn't want to claim it's a panacea or a sure thing.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Many years ago, I considered what might inhibit the alignment of collective human will with artificial intelligence. One factor is the low data rate of humans, particularly our slow output rate. Because communication is so slow, it diminishes the connection between humans and computers. The more we become like a tree, the less we understand what the tree is experiencing. For example, if you look at a tree or a plant and want to make it happy, it doesn't communicate much. Therefore, increasing the data rate that humans can intake is essential.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: If we can significantly increase the output rate of AI, we could better align collective human will with AI. I believe there's potential to increase the output rate by three, six, or even more orders of magnitude, which would improve the current situation. This increase could be achieved by enhancing the number of electrodes and channels, as well as possibly implanting multiple Neuralinks. Do you think there will be a world in the next couple of decades where hundreds of millions of people have Neuralink? I do.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: If the capabilities of superhuman abilities are demonstrated to be extremely safe, many people would likely choose to adopt them. For instance, if you could upload your memories, you wouldn't lose any. This technology could potentially supersede cell phones. The biggest issue with phones is figuring out what you want, which is why features like auto-complete exist. However, from a human perspective, the output is still very slow.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Our phones are desperately trying to understand what we want. There's a disconnect with every keystroke from a computer standpoint. The computer is communicating with a slow-moving tree that’s trying to respond. Computers can perform trillions of instructions per second, and if a whole second goes by, there are a trillion things they could have done. I think it's exciting and scary for people because a very high bit rate changes the human experience in ways that are hard to imagine. We would become something different, perhaps a sort of futuristic cyborg.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: We're obviously talking about the distant future, but it's not super far away—maybe 10 to 15 years. When can I get one? Probably in less than 10 years, depending on what you want to do. If I can get a TH000 BPS that's safe and allows me to interact with a computer while relaxing, that would be great. There are certain aspects of human-computer interaction that can be done more efficiently and enjoyably. We feel pretty confident that we might see advancements within the next year or so.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Someone with a Neuralink implant will be able to outperform a pro gamer because their reaction time would be faster. I got to visit Memphis, and you're going big on compute. You've also said, "Play to win or don't play at all." So, what does it take to win? For AI, it means having the most powerful training compute, and the rate of improvement in training compute has to be faster than everyone else's; otherwise, you will not win, and your AI will be inferior. 

How can Grock 3, which might be available next year—hopefully by the end of this year—be the best LLM?

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The best AI system in the world relies on several factors: compute, data, post-training processes, and the way the product is packaged. It's similar to a Formula 1 race—both the car and the driver are important. If your car has only half the horsepower of a competitor's, even the best driver will likely lose. Conversely, if your car has twice the horsepower, even a mediocre driver may win. In this analogy, the training compute is like the engine's horsepower. Therefore, it's crucial to optimize all these components.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
To achieve the best results, it's important to consider how efficiently you use training compute and perform inference with AI. This ultimately comes down to human talent. Additionally, unique access to data plays a significant role. 

Regarding Twitter data, I believe that most leading AI companies have already scraped all available Twitter data. Moving forward, the real value lies in the immediacy of the data, as it's challenging for companies to scrape in real time. This gives Gro a distinct advantage, especially with Tesla.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Real-time video coming from several million cars, and ultimately tens of millions, combined with Optimus, could lead to hundreds of millions, or even billions, of Optimus robots. These robots will learn a tremendous amount from the real world. I believe that Optimus will be the biggest source of data because it scales with reality. It's humbling to realize how little data humans have actually accumulated. When considering how many trillions of usable tokens humans have generated—discounting spam and repetitive content—the number is not huge, and we run out pretty quickly.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Tesla cars can stay on the road, while the Optimus robot can go anywhere, including off-road. For example, it can pick up a cup and determine if it did so correctly. It can assess whether it poured water into the cup, if the water went in, or if it spilled. These are simple tasks, but the robot can perform them at scale, generating useful data from reality and understanding cause and effect.

To achieve mass production of humanoid robots like that, it requires a similar approach to car manufacturing. The global capacity for vehicles is about 100 million annually.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
The demand for vehicles is around 100 million per year, with roughly 2 billion vehicles currently in use. This makes sense considering the average lifespan of a vehicle is about 20 years. At steady state, producing 100 million vehicles annually aligns with a 2 billion vehicle fleet. 

In contrast, the utility of humanoid robots is significantly greater. I estimate that the demand for humanoid robots could exceed a billion units per year. However, before you began developing Optimus, many believed it was an extremely difficult problem to solve. While it's still a challenging task, creating Optimus is a significant step forward, even though it currently struggles with basic tasks like walking in the park.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: It can walk in a park, which is not too difficult, but it will be able to traverse a wide range of terrain and pick up various objects. They can already do that with all kinds of objects. Pouring water into a cup is not trivial, as there are many different types of containers. There will be an immense amount of engineering dedicated to the hand; it might account for close to half of all the engineering in Optimus from an electromechanical standpoint. Additionally, a significant portion of human intelligence is applied to what we do with our hands.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Manipulation of objects in the world requires intelligent and safe techniques. When you think about how your hand works, it’s fascinating. The sensory control of our hands is significant, and we have large hands. The muscles that actuate your hand are primarily located in your forearm. While there are a few small muscles in the hand itself, it essentially functions as a skeleton with muscles and tendons. The muscles controlling your fingers are in your forearm and pass through the carpal tunnel, which is a small passageway.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The design of the bones and the tiny tunnel through which the tendons pass is crucial. These tendons primarily control hand movement. To achieve this functionality in Optimus, we need to re-engineer the tendons. Initially, we tried placing the actuators in the hand itself, but this resulted in oversized hands that looked awkward and lacked sufficient degrees of freedom and strength. This realization led us to the conclusion that the actuators should be placed in the forearm. Just like in a human hand, cables must run through a narrow tunnel to operate the fingers. Additionally, there is a reason for not having all the fingers.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: It wouldn't be expensive from an energy or evolutionary standpoint to have all your fingers be the same length, so why not? Actually, it's better to have different lengths. Your dexterity improves with fingers of varying lengths; there are more tasks you can perform. For instance, having a little finger is beneficial for fine motor skills. If you lost your little finger, you would notice a significant decrease in dexterity. As you figure out this problem, consider these factors.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: We need to find a way to mass manufacture it, making it as simple as possible. However, achieving simplicity is quite complicated. Creating a humanoid robot that can perform tasks like a human is a high bar to reach. Our new arm has 22 degrees of freedom instead of 11, with actuators located in the forearm. All the actuators and sensors are designed from scratch based on first principles. We will continue to invest significant engineering effort into improving the hand, which includes the entire forearm from the elbow forward.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The engineering behind creating a human-like robot is incredibly challenging. Even the simplest version that can perform most, though not all, human tasks is still very complex. Can you discuss what it takes for a great engineering team? From what I observed in Memphis, the supercomputer cluster demonstrates an intense drive toward simplifying processes, understanding them, and constantly improving and iterating. While it's easy to say "simplify," the reality is much more complicated.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
It's very difficult to do this. I have a basic first principles algorithm that I follow as a mantra. First, I question the requirements and aim to make them less flawed. Requirements are always imperfect to some degree, so it's important to start by reducing their number. text: No matter how good your decoder is, if your updates occur every 30 or 50 milliseconds, the result will be choppy. This can be frustrating and lead to challenges. At that point, it became clear that the main challenge was to reliably get the data off the device, enabling us to tackle the next challenge. Eventually, the focus shifted to the modeling challenge: how to build an effective mapping. This involved the supervised learning problem of having a dataset with labels and predicting the optimal neurodecoder architecture and hyperparameters to optimize performance.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Once we solved the initial bottleneck, the next challenge was software stability and reliability. If there are widely varying inference latencies or if the app lags occasionally, it disrupts the user experience and makes it difficult to maintain a state of flow. We identified various software bugs and made improvements that significantly increased the system's performance, reliability, and stability. This allowed us to reliably collect data to build better models, addressing a significant problem we faced for a while.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
If I were to guess, there are two major directions for improving BPS further. The first is labeling, which is a fundamental challenge. Given a window of time where the user is expressing behavioral intent, we need to determine what they are trying to do at the granularity of every millisecond. This is a task design problem, a UX problem, a machine learning problem, and a software problem, touching on all these different domains. 

The second direction for improvement is either completely changing what you're decoding or extending the number of things you're decoding. This approach serves the overall goal of enhancing BPS.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The direction of functionality can be imagined as providing more clicks, such as left clicks, right clicks, and middle clicks, along with different actions like click and drag. This can improve the effective bit rate of your communication prosthesis, allowing users to express themselves through various communication channels. You can measure this in bits per second, but what truly matters is how effectively users can navigate their computers. From the perspective of the downstream tasks that are important, enhancing functionality is a key interest because it can improve both the number of bits per second and overall user experience.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The user's independence and their skill and efficiency in operating a computer can indeed be enhanced by increasing the number of threads. The short answer is yes, but the relationship is nuanced. If you plot a curve of the number of channels used for decoding against either the offline metric of decoding quality or the online metric of user performance, you'll observe a logarithmic curve. As the number of channels increases, there is a corresponding logarithmic improvement in control quality and offline validation.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Metrics are important. The key nuance here is that each channel corresponds to a specific intention in the brain. For example, channel 254 might correspond to moving to the right, while channel 256 could mean moving to the left. If you want to expand the number of functions you can control, it's essential to have a broader set of channels that covers a wider range of imagined movements. You can think of it like Mr. Potato Head; if you had various imagined movements, how would you map those to input for a computer? For instance, you could envision handwriting to output characters on the screen or typing with your hands.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: You could imagine different finger modulations for various clicks, or wiggling your nose to open a menu, or using your big toe to trigger a command like "tab." The number of actions you can take depends on how many channels you have and the information they carry. As you increase the number of threads, you also increase the number of actions you can perform. It's important to note that our goal is to enable a broader range of interactions.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I aim to enable users with paralysis to control the computer as quickly as possible, maintaining all the same functionalities we discussed. Reliability is crucial, and this ties into the channel count discussion. As the number of channels increases, the relative importance of any specific feature of your model's input to the user's output control diminishes. This means that if the neural nonstationarity effect is per channel, or if the noise is independent, then having more channels generally leads to a reduced output effect. Consequently, the reliability of the system will improve. My core thesis is that increasing the channel count should enhance the system's reliability.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Can you elaborate on the reliability of the decoder? When you mention the nonstationarity of the signal, which aspect are you referring to? 

Let's briefly discuss what the underlying signal looks like. As I mentioned earlier, when you imagine moving to the right or left, neurons may fire more or less, and the frequency content of that signal—especially in the motor cortex—is closely correlated with the intended output and the behavioral task the user is performing. It's important to note that rate coding, which describes this phenomenon, is not the only way the brain can represent information; there are many possibilities.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: There are different ways in which the brain encodes intention. For example, evidence from bats suggests that there are temporal codes, where the timing of neuron firing represents information. However, in the motor cortex, substantial evidence indicates that it primarily uses rate coding. This means that the brain represents information by changing the frequency of neuron firing. What matters is the difference between the baseline state of a neuron and its modulated state. Observations in both practical and academic work show that this baseline rate is significant.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: If you imagine measuring flour when baking, the baseline weight of the pot can vary from day to day. If you're trying to measure how much rice is in the pot, you'll get different measurements on different days because you're using different pots. This shifting baseline is a key factor causing downstream bias. There can be other non-linear effects, but at a first-order level, what we observe is that the baseline firing rate of any particular neuron or channel is changing.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: You adjust to the baseline to make it relative to the baseline. This is a great question. With monkeys, we have found various ways to do this. One example is asking them to perform a behavioral task, like playing a game with a joystick. We measure brain activity, compute the mean of what's happening across all input features, and then subtract that from the input during the BCI session. This approach works well for monkeys, but it doesn't work as effectively with Nolan. I don't know the full reason why, but I can imagine several explanations. One possibility is that the contextual effects between open-loop and closed-loop tasks are much more significant with Nolan.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
It may be more challenging for a monkey in this open-loop task. For example, he might be watching the Lex Fridman podcast, whistling, listening to music, talking with a friend, and asking his mom what's for dinner while performing the task. The difference in context between these two states could be significant, leading to a larger generalization gap between the features normalized during open-loop time and those used during closed-loop time. 

On that point, it's impressive to see Noan multitask—managing to move the mouse cursor effectively while talking and feeling nervous about speaking in front of others.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Kicking my ass in chess too, while talking trash at the same time. If you're trying to normalize to the baseline, that might throw everything off. That's interesting. 

For those who aren't familiar with assistive technology, there's a common belief that you can simply use an eye tracker to help someone move a mouse on the screen. It's a fair question, and I wasn't confident before that this would be a profoundly transformative technology for people like him. However, I am now very confident that it will be, and the reasons are...

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: It really has to do with how ergonomically it fits into their lives. Even if you can offer the same level of control as an eye tracker or a mouse, you don’t need to have that device in your face. You don’t need to be positioned a certain way, and you don’t need your caretaker to be around to set it up for you. You can activate it whenever and however you want, wherever you want. That level of independence is game-changing for people. It means they can text a friend at night privately without their mom needing to be in the loop. It allows them to browse the internet at 2 a.m. when nobody is around to set up their iPad for them. This is a profoundly transformative change for many individuals.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
The situation is critical, especially for individuals who may not be able to communicate at all or ask for help. This technology could potentially be their only link to the outside world, which is profoundly impactful. You mentioned the neural decoder; how much machine learning is involved in it? How much is based on science, art, or even magic? How challenging is it to create a decoder that interprets these sequences of spikes?

That's a good question. There are a couple of different ways to approach this. Let me provide a broader perspective first before diving deeper into the specifics. The overall process of building the decoder is...

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
The process of building the dataset and compiling it into the weights is crucial. I believe that further improvement will primarily focus on the dataset side, specifically how to construct optimal labels for the model. However, there is also a separate challenge in compiling the best model. 

One of the main challenges in designing the optimal model for Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) is that offline metrics do not necessarily correspond to online metrics. It is fundamentally a control problem; the user is trying to control something on the screen, and the user experience of how you output their intention significantly impacts the overall effectiveness.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
The ability to control the model is important. For instance, if you only look at validation loss as predicted by your model, there can be multiple ways to achieve the same validation loss. However, not all of these methods are equally controllable by the end user. It might seem straightforward to add auxiliary loss terms to help capture the important factors, but this is a complex and nuanced process. Transforming the labels into the model involves more intricacies than a standard supervised learning problem.

One fascinating anecdote involves our experiments with various neural network architectures that translate brain data into velocity outputs. One example that stands out in my mind is from a couple of years ago.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Years ago, we were using fully connected networks to decode brain activity. We conducted an A/B test to measure the relative performance in online control sessions of 1D convolution over the input signal. Imagine having a sliding window per channel that produces convolved features for each input sequence across all channels simultaneously. This approach resulted in better validation metrics, meaning it fit the data better and generalized more effectively on offline data. By using this convolutional architecture, we reduced the number of parameters, which is a standard procedure when dealing with time series data. It turns out that when using that model...

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Online, the controllability was far worse, even though the offline metrics were better. There are many ways to interpret that, but what it taught me is that, at least for now, if you throw a lot of compute at this problem and try to hyperparameter optimize or let a GBT model generate various solutions, simply optimizing for loss is not sufficient. This indicates that there is still an inherent modeling gap and some artistry left to uncover in how to scale your model with more compute. This may be fundamentally a labeling problem, but there could be other components involved as well, such as data.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: It sounds like the main issue is data quality rather than data quantity. However, the quantity of interactions is also a factor, as the model needs to be trained on these interactions, and there aren't that many available. The discussion varies depending on the version being referenced. For instance, if we consider a simple example like 2D velocity, data quality is indeed the primary concern. However, if we're discussing how to create a multifunction output that allows for various inputs, similar to what you and I can do, the process becomes much more sophisticated.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The nuance in modeling presents a challenge because you need to consider not only when the user is left-clicking but also ensure that the model does not trigger when they are right-clicking or moving the mouse. One interesting bug from week one of BCI with Nolan occurred when he moved the mouse; the click signal dropped significantly, and when he stopped clicking, it increased again. This indicates contamination between the two inputs. Another example was when he attempted to perform a left click and drag; as soon as he started moving, the left click signal dropped off sharply. This again highlights the issue of contamination.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Between the two signals, you need to develop a way, either in the dataset or in the model, to build robustness against this kind of variability. Think of it like overfitting; the model simply hasn't encountered this variability before. It's essential to find a method to assist the model with this challenge. This is exciting because it feels very solvable, although it is fundamentally an engineering challenge. It's important to emphasize that it may not require fundamentally new techniques. For instance, individuals working on unsupervised speech classification using CTC loss could potentially have very applicable skills for this problem.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
I'm excited about the future development of the software stack on Neuralink. There are two main aspects I'm looking forward to: the technology itself and how it will be integrated into the world. 

From a technological perspective, I'm eager to see how this device can assist individuals who cannot speak at all and have no ability to use voice commands for control. Understanding how it can empower those with extremely limited capabilities will be incredibly valuable.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Understanding product-market fit is crucial for all startups. We need to assess whether this device has the capacity and potential to transform people's lives in its current state. Currently, we have a 1,000-channel device, but the next version will feature between 3,000 and 6,000 channels. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Problems will disappear completely at that scale, but some will remain and require further focus. Additionally, when we reach that point and start dramatically expanding the set of functions that one brain can output, we must address the nuances of user experience, such as the inability to feel different keys under our fingertips while still maintaining functionality.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: To modulate all of them in synchrony and achieve the desired outcome, you need to consider how to make this intuitive for users controlling a high-dimensional control surface without physical feedback. This presents an intriguing challenge. I'm also excited to explore whether these scaling laws continue as we increase the channel count. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: When you place more electrodes in the brain, you can learn more quickly about what those brain regions represent. I'm excited about this fundamental neuroscience learning, which is also crucial for determining how to most efficiently insert electrodes in the future. I’m really enthusiastic about all these dimensions, and that doesn't even touch on the software stack we work on every day and what we're currently developing. It seems virtually impossible to me that a thousand electrodes is the saturation point; it feels like a notion from the future where we should obviously have millions of electrodes.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: True breakthroughs happen when thoughts are expressed in poetry. You tweeted that some thoughts are most precisely described in poetry. Why do you think that is? I believe it's because the information bottleneck of language is quite steep. However, poetry allows us to reconstruct meaning in another person's brain more effectively without being literal. If you can express a sentiment in a way that enables them to reconstruct the true underlying meaning and beauty of what you're trying to convey, the generator function in their brain becomes more powerful than what language can express. The mechanism of poetry is essentially to feed or seed that generator.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Being literal can sometimes be a suboptimal way to convey meaning. It's during the user's process of generating understanding that they grasp what you mean. That's the beautiful part. When you look at a beautiful painting, it's not just the pixels that are captivating; it's the thought process and experience that matter. It resonates with something deep within you that the artist also experienced and conveyed through their work. This concept will be relevant for full-on telepathy.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Reading poetry literally often doesn't convey much meaning. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Some people believe we've achieved AGI, but I think there's a significant aspect to consider: the ability to appreciate music. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: We're on the next theme, and they play with the timing of surprises and user expectations. This has been true throughout history as musicians evolve. Ultimately, it must be about the listener.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The discussion about which rule is the right one to break revolves around the user's or audience member's perception of what is interesting. What do you think is the meaning of human existence? podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I think the analogy for the meaning of life is that we often don't know the right questions to ask. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast

It's interesting how much value you assign to the task of asking the right questions. That's the main point; it's not about the answers, but the questions. Well, Bliss, thank you for everything you do, for being you, and for talking with us.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Thank you for listening to this conversation with Bliss Chapman. Now, dear friends, here's Nolan, our boss and the first human being to have a Neuralink device implanted in his brain. 

Nolan, you had a diving accident in 2016 that left you paralyzed from the shoulders down. How did that accident change your life? 

It was a freak incident. Imagine running into the ocean—though it was a lake—and getting to about waist height before diving under a wave. That's what I did, but I never came back up. I'm not sure what happened. I was running into the water with a couple of guys, and my understanding of the incident is...

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I took a stray fist, elbow, knee, or foot to the left side of my head. It was sore for about a month afterward, so it must have been a pretty big knock. Then, both of them came up, and I didn't, so I was face down in the water for a while. I was conscious but eventually realized I couldn't hold my breath any longer. I keep saying I took a big drink, and I don't know if people like that I say it; it seems like I'm making light of the situation. But this is just how I am—I'm a very relaxed, stress-free person. I rolled with the punches and took it in stride, thinking, "All right, well..."

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: What can I do next to improve my life, even a little bit, on a day-to-day basis? Initially, I focused on healing my body as much as possible and trying to get off the ventilator. I aimed to learn as much as I could to ensure my survival after leaving the hospital. Thankfully, I had my family around me. Without my parents and siblings, I wouldn't have made it this far; they've done so much for me—more than I can ever repay. Many people in my situation don't have that support. Some families are either unable to provide care or simply don't want to, leaving individuals to be placed in difficult circumstances.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Thankfully, I have my family and a great group of friends from college who have rallied around me. We are incredibly close. People often say that if you're lucky, you'll end up with one or two friends from high school that you keep throughout your life. I have about 10 to 12 friends from high school who have all stuck around, and we still get together twice a year for what we call the spring series and the fall series. 

During our last gathering, we dressed up as X-Men, and I went as Professor Xavier. It was awesome! I have such a great support system around me, so being a quadriplegic isn't that bad. I get waited on all the time, with people bringing me food and drinks.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
I get to sit around and watch as much TV, movies, and anime as I want. I can read as much as I want. It's great; it's beautiful to see the silver lining in all of this. 

Do you remember the moment when you first realized you were paralyzed from the neck down? 

Yes, I was face down in the water. When something hit my head, I tried to get up and realized I couldn't move. It just clicked for me: I was paralyzed and couldn't get up or flip over. I knew I would eventually drown if I couldn't hold my breath forever, so I held my breath and thought about it for maybe 10 to 15 seconds. I've heard from others...

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
The two girls who pulled me out of the water were two of my best friends and lifeguards. One of them mentioned that it looked like my body was shaking in the water, as if I was trying to flip over. I knew immediately what my situation was and realized that from that point on, I might need help at the hospital. 

When I was in the hospital, right before surgery, I tried to calm one of my friends down. I had brought her with me from college to camp, and she was really upset. I told her it was going to be fine and tried to lighten the mood by cracking some jokes. The nurse had called my mom, and I was...

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Don't tell my mom; she's just going to be stressed out. Call her after I'm out of surgery because at least she'll have some answers then, whether I live or not. I didn't want her to be stressed throughout the whole thing. When I first woke up after surgery, I was super drugged up. They had me on fentanyl in multiple ways, which was intense. I don't recommend it, but I saw some crazy stuff on that fentanyl, and it was still the best I've ever felt on medication. I remember the first time I saw my mom in the hospital; I was just crying. I had a ventilator in, so I couldn't talk or anything, and I started crying more from seeing her than anything else.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
The whole situation was obviously pretty rough. Seeing her face for the first time was hard. However, I never had a moment of thinking, "I'm paralyzed; this sucks; I don't want to be around anymore." It was always more about hating that I had to deal with this, but I realized that sitting here and wallowing wasn't going to help. So, there was immediate acceptance.

Has there been a low point along the way? Yes, there have been days when I didn't feel like doing anything. Not so much anymore—over the last couple of years, I haven't felt that way. I've wanted to do anything possible to make my life better. But at the beginning, there were definitely some ups and downs.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Some really hard things to adjust to. First off, during the first couple of months, the amount of pain I was in was incredibly difficult. I remember screaming at the top of my lungs in the hospital because I thought my legs were on fire. Even though I couldn't feel anything, it was all nerve pain, and that was a really tough night. I asked the staff for as much pain medication as possible, but they told me I had reached my limit and suggested I try to go to a happy place. That was a pretty low point for me.

Additionally, it's challenging to realize that there are things I wanted to do in my life that I won't be able to anymore. I always wanted to be a husband and father, but I just don't think I could do that now.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: As a quadriplegic, I wonder if it's possible, but I'm not sure I would want to put someone I love through the challenges of taking care of me. Not being able to participate in sports has been difficult, as I was a huge athlete growing up. It's the little things that hit hard too; for instance, I miss the simple pleasure of holding a book, feeling its texture, and smelling its pages as I turn them. I just love that experience, and I can't do it anymore. The two-year mark was particularly rough. They say that after two years, you will regain as much movement and sensation as you're ever going to get back. So, for the first two years, that was the focus.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
The only thing on my mind was trying to move my fingers, hands, and feet to regain sensation and movement. When the two-year mark hit on June 30, 2018, I felt really sad about my situation. However, I was never depressed for long periods; it just never seemed worthwhile to me. 

What gave me strength was my faith in God. I believed that everything happened for a purpose, even if that purpose didn't involve Neuralink. There's a well-known story in the Bible about Job, who faced numerous terrible challenges.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: He praises God throughout the whole situation. I think many people believe they are like Job, going through something terrible, and that if they just praise God, everything will eventually work out. After my accident, I realized I might not be Job; I could be one of His children who faces tragedy, like being killed or kidnapped. It's about the terrible things that happen to those we love. In this case, my mom might be like Job, having to endure something extraordinarily hard. I just need to support her and help her through it as best as I can.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
I have been going through a massive trial, and that has given me a lot of strength. My family and friends provide me with the support I need on a day-to-day basis, which makes things much easier. From everything I've seen of you online, your streams, and the way you are today, I really admire your unwavering positive outlook on life. Has it always been this way? 

Yes, I’ve always believed I could do anything I set my mind to. There was never anything too big for me. I didn’t want to do a lot; I wanted to travel around, be sort of like a gypsy, and work odd jobs.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I've always dreamed of traveling around Europe, experiencing life as a shepherd in Wales or Ireland, and then becoming a fisherman in Italy. These may seem like cliché ideas, but I think it would be so much fun to travel and try different things for a year. I've always seen the best in people and have tried to be good to those around me. Growing up with my mom, who is the most positive and energetic person in the world, has influenced me greatly. I'm a people person and genuinely enjoy meeting new individuals. I just wanted to embrace every opportunity. It's great to see that cynicism hasn't taken over, despite everything we've faced.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Was that a deliberate choice you made to not let this keep you down? 

Yeah, a bit. It's just how I am. I roll with the punches. I always tell people that I don't stress much. When I see others getting stressed, I say, "It's not hard; just don't stress about it." They often respond, "That's not how that works." But it works for me—just don't stress, and everything will be fine. Of course, not everything always goes well, and it doesn't always work out for the best, but I don't think stress has had any place in my life since I was young.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: In a chair that was uncomfortable, I felt like there was something significant happening. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast

As for the first time I felt I could use the Neuralink device to affect the world around me, the initial experience was actually not...

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: After surgery, some members of the Neuralink team brought in a tablet and displayed eight different channels recording my neuron spikes. I found that fascinating, and everyone else did too.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Around me, people were asking, "What are you seeing?" I pointed out, "Look at this one, the top row, third box over. This yellow spike— that's me right there!" podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
I mapped out maybe a hundred different things, but the big yellow spike was the one that stood out to me. Could you speak to what it's like to wiggle your fingers? Imagine the cognitive effort required to wiggle your index finger, for example. How easy is that to do?

That's fascinating. 

Yes, it is bizarre, but that's part of the process.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The recovery process involves consistently trying to move your body every day as much as possible. The nervous system begins to reconnect itself. For some people, this process may not work, while others, like me, regain some control. I managed to get some bicep control back, and if I try hard enough, I can wiggle some of my fingers. I know there’s potential for movement in a few of my fingers as well. That's the advice given to me. One of the people who visited me in the hospital shared a story about another patient who had...

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Most of his control was recovered, but what he thought about every day was actually the act of walking, over and over again. I tried that for years—imagining walking. It's hard to visualize all the steps involved in taking a step, including all the movements and activations that occur in your leg. You're not just imagining it; you're trying to do it. It's about recalling what I had to do to take a step, which is something none of us typically think about. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
I tried to recreate that in my head as much as I could and then practiced it repeatedly. It's not like a third-person perspective; it's a first-person perspective. You're not just imagining yourself walking; you're literally doing everything as if you're walking. It was hard at the beginning—frustrating and cognitively challenging. 

There's a scene in one of the Kill Bill movies where the character is paralyzed, possibly from a drug. She finds a way to get into the back of a truck and stares at her toe, telling it to move, saying, "Move your big toe."

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: After a few seconds on screen, she began to move her body parts until she could move again. I did that for years, staring at my body and telling myself to move my index finger or my big toe. Sometimes I vocalized it out loud, and other times I just thought it. I tried every different method to regain some movement. It was surprisingly taxing on my body, which I never expected, since I wasn't physically moving. It felt like there was a buildup of signals that weren't getting through from my brain due to the gap in my condition.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The signals from my brain travel down the spinal cord and then back up from my hand to the brain. It feels like those signals get stuck in the body part I'm trying to move, building up until they burst. Once they burst, I experience a strange sensation as everything dissipates back to normal. It's also a fatigue issue, similar to muscle fatigue, but without actually moving my muscles, which is very bizarre. If I try to focus on a body part and think about moving it for two, three, four, or sometimes eight hours, it becomes very taxing on my mind and requires a lot of concentration. It was easier at the beginning because I wasn't able to control it as much.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I didn't have control over my environment for the first few years, so I spent a lot of time just staring at walls. During that time, I did a lot of thinking and tried to move repeatedly. I never gave up hope; I was essentially training hard. I still do this subconsciously, and I believe it helped a lot with Neuralink. I mentioned this recently at the All Hands meeting at the Neuralink facility in Austin. By the way, welcome to Austin! I went to Texas A&M, so I've been around for a while. You should be saying welcome!

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Welcome to Texas! I was talking about how a lot of what they've had me do, especially at the beginning and still now, is body mapping. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Other paralyzed people may give up, but I hope they don't. I hope they keep trying because I've heard many say, "Don't ever stop." I know it's possible, and I'll never give up. I practice wiggling my fingers while lying down and watching TV; it has become something I do almost instinctively.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I don't think I'll ever stop. It's really awesome to hear because I believe it's one of those things that can pay off in the long term. Honestly, I think Neuralink gave me the ability to visually see that what I'm doing is actually having an effect. I can't express my appreciation enough for that. It's a huge part of the reason why I know I'm going to keep doing it forever. Before Neuralink, I was training every day, just assuming that things were happening.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I didn't know I wasn't getting back any mobility or sensation, so I could have been running up against a brick wall for all I knew. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The brain can control a lot, so what did it feel like when you first wiggled your index finger and saw the environment respond? It was very cool, but I keep telling people it made sense to me. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I really liked how it all set in for me. I understood that when I tried to move a body part, it could be mapped using a machine learning algorithm to identify my brain signals. Although I didn't know all the details, it made sense that there were still signals firing in my brain; they just couldn't get through due to a gap in my spinal cord. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The difference between attempted movement and imagined movement is fascinating. Attempted movement involves physically trying to move, such as moving my hand to the right, left, forward, or back. It includes actions like lifting my finger up and down or attempting to kick. Even if the movement isn't visible, I'm still making the effort, like trying to shrug my shoulders. That's what I was doing for the first couple of weeks when they were...

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: When I was doing body mapping, I was trying to gain cursor control. Near suggested that I imagine performing the actions, which made sense to me. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Movement never really connected with me. You could describe it like a professional athlete swinging a baseball bat or a golf club. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
When I first moved the cursor, I felt that it should happen, and I wasn't surprised by that. Can you clarify if there's a difference between imagined movement and attempted movement?

Not necessarily. I think all these signals can still be represented in the motor cortex. The difference seems to relate to the naturalness of imagining something versus attempting it, as well as the fatigue that can occur over time. By the way, the mic is bliss.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: This is just different ways to prompt you to get to the concept of attempted movement. It does sound like the right approach. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: It was very hard at the beginning, but I attempted it, and it worked just like it should. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I noticed that I didn't have to exert as much effort to move, which I discussed with them. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: What I wanted to do started percolating in my mind. It was always there in the background, and I found it intriguing how it could work. I wondered what it meant in terms of using Neuralink. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I was trying to train my eyes to focus ahead on a target. I realized that if I looked at a different target, I could get there more quickly. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: It made me realize that this technology is much more impressive and cooler than I ever thought. It opened up a whole new world of possibilities regarding what could happen with this technology and what I might be capable of. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: It felt like I had discovered something significant, though perhaps not for the world at large or the field itself. It was an "aha" moment for me—realizing that this approach works. It's not strictly one or the other; I don't only use attempted movements or only imagined movements. Instead, I use them in parallel, allowing me to focus on whatever I'm doing.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I like to experiment with different ideas. Occasionally, I'll get a thought in my head, like, "I wonder if this works," and I'll start trying it out. Afterwards, I'll mention to the team that I wasn't following the original plan; I just had an idea I wanted to explore. If it seems to work, we should consider exploring it further. I believe that discovery isn't just for me; it's also a discovery for everyone else who uses your link. It's not always obvious that something is even possible. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast

For those who don't know, can you explain how the Link app works? You had an amazing stream on this topic, your first stream on X, where you described the app. Could you elaborate on how it functions? 

Sure! The Link app, created by Neuralink, helps me interact with a computer. It features various settings and modes that I can use, including body mapping.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: We touched on calibration, which is how I achieve cursor control. It involves translating brain activity into cursor movement. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
For a long time, I've been discussing the difference between the two from a technical perspective. It would be great to hear your side of the story.
