podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I will follow that cursor the whole time, and it will train based on my intentions throughout the process. When you say "follow," you don't mean with your eyes; you mean with your intentions. Generally, for calibration, I'm doing attempted movements because I believe it works better. The better models I develop as I progress through calibration make it easier to use imagined movement. Calibration based on attempted movement creates a model that is really effective for using the force. I’ve tried calibration with imagined movement, but it doesn’t work as well for some reason. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I have a task where a random target appears on the screen, and I move to follow the cursor to that target across the screen. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: After a certain point, I can feel it; I can tell it moves differently. That's the best way I can describe it. It's almost as if it anticipates what I'm going to do before I do it. After attempting movement for 15 minutes, I can sense that when I move my eyes to the next target, the cursor starts to pick up on it. It's like it's learning what I'm going to do. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: It's interesting to explore how different calibrations affect the experience. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
It makes sense to me that we've done it with a cursor and without a cursor in open loop. For example, during the center-out calibration, a bubble lights up, and I push towards it. You're full of great references! Is the bubble game fun? I always feel bad when they make me do calibration, especially when I know we're about to do a 40-minute session.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The higher the BPS, the better my score, which indicates that I'm performing well. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Change things based on that if the number isn't always accurate regarding how the model will turn out or the end result. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: To get a score on the calibrations, like measuring speed from Bubble to Bubble, there are two phases: open loop and closed loop. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The calibration process usually takes about 10 to 15 minutes. However, the team is working hard to reduce that time significantly. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
I think that's the dream. Right now, my goal is to get really good models. I'm in calibration for 40 to 45 minutes, and while it can be tough, I don't mind. If it means getting a model that can break records on web grid, I would stay in it for two hours. 

Now, let's talk business. I saw a presentation where Bliss mentioned that by March, you selected 89,000 targets for web grid. Can you explain what web grid is and what it takes to be a world-class performer as you continue to break world records? 

It's like being a gold medalist. I’d like to thank everyone who has helped me get here—my coaches, my parents for driving me to practice, and so on.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
I practice every day at 5 in the morning. I like to thank God and acknowledge my dedication. The interviews with athletes follow a specific template. 

Web grid is literally just a grid that can be made as big or small as needed. A single box on that grid will light up, and you click it. This method allows them to benchmark how effective a BCI is. It's straightforward: only one blue cell appears, and you're supposed to move the mouse to it and click. I prefer playing on larger grids because the bigger the grid, the more bits per second (BPS) you get with each click. For example, I often play on a 35x35 grid.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Those little squares, called targets, will light up. You move the cursor there and click it, and you do that repeatedly. Initially, I achieved eight bits per second, but I recently broke that record. I'm currently at 8.5 bits per second. I almost beat my record the day before I came to Austin, but I experienced a five-second lag at the end. I had to wait for the latency to calm down before I could continue clicking. I was at 8.01 bits per second, and after the lag, the next three targets I clicked all stayed at 8.01. If I had been able to click during that lag, I might have reached nine bits per second.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
I'm really close, but this whole Austin trip has gotten in the way of my web grid playing ability. It's frustrating. That's all I've been thinking about right now. I just want to do better at nine; I know it's very achievable, and I'm right there. I think I could hit ten in the next month, maybe even in the next few weeks if I really push myself. 

You and Elon are basically the same person. The last time I did a podcast with him, he came in extremely frustrated because he couldn't beat Uber Lilith as a Droid. That was about a year ago. I could tell that a percentage of his brain was occupied with that thought the entire time.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I wish I were attempting that right now. I think he did it that night; he stayed up and accomplished it, which is crazy to me. In a fundamental way, it's really inspiring. What you're doing is inspiring because it's not just about the game. Everything you're doing has an impact. By striving to excel in web grid, you're helping everyone figure out how to create the system—decoding the software, the hardware, the calibration—making all of that work so you can perform everything else really well. It's just really fun. That's also part of it—making it fun. It's addictive. I've joked about what they actually did when they went in.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
They must have flipped a switch in my brain to make me more susceptible to these kinds of games, making me addicted to something like web Grid. Do you know Bliss's high score? He said it was like 14 or something, but I think it’s actually 17.1 or 177. When Nolan first played this game, he asked how good we were at it, and I think you told him right then that you were going to try to beat me. I believe you can do it, and I’m excited for that! So, I’ve been playing first with the dwell cursor.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: My web grid playing ability is really hampered because I have to wait three seconds for every click. So, I can't just click; I have to dwell for three seconds, which slows me down significantly. Despite this, I still manage to hit around 50 trials per minute, which is pretty good. I can gauge when I'm approaching that threshold and start the click a bit early, so I'm not fully stopped over the target when I go to click.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: You're trying to time it just right, but you're slowing down a bit before the TS. This is like a lead performance. It’s frustrating that there's a ceiling of three, but I can get down to 0.2 and 0.1. I've experimented with that, but I need to adjust a lot of different parameters to work with 0.1, and I don't have control over all of that yet. It also affects how the models are trained. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
I need a better model. When I use 3 versus 0.1, the models behave differently. The interactions are significantly different, so I have to be cautious. I found that using 3 is actually better in some ways, unless I can use 0.1 and adjust all the different parameters, which would be ideal since 0.3 is faster than 0.1. I can get there. 

Right now, can you focus on hover clicking with the dwell cursor? Before all the thread retraction issues, we were calibrating left and right clicks. My previous record, before I broke it again with the dwell cursor, was on a 35x35 grid using left and right clicks.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: To achieve more bits per second (BPS) using multiple clicks, it's more challenging. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Some of the threads retracted, which was really hard to hear. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Many doors had opened up for me, creating so many possibilities that I didn't want to lose them. After a month, I thought it would be a cruel twist of fate to see the view from the top of the mountain and then have it all come crashing down. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: This won't ruin my day. I'm not going to let it affect this amazing tour they have set up for me. I want to show everyone how much I appreciate all the work they're doing. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: If I could keep providing data in any way, I would do that. I was just happy to be a part of it, and everything I experienced was a perk. I know how amazing it will be for everyone who comes after me, so I might as well keep pushing forward. With that said, you were able to get to work on your...

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The journey to regain my performance felt like going from Rocky One to Rocky Two. When did I first realize this was possible? It was within a couple of weeks. However, there was a turning point when they changed how they measured the neuron spikes in my brain, which helped me significantly.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: We were measuring the behavior of individual neurons and switched from individual spike detection to something called spike band power. If you watched the previous segments with either me or DJ, you might have some context. When they made that switch, it was a light bulb moment; I realized this works and we can run with it. I noticed an immediate uptick in performance. I could feel it when they switched over; it was better. Everything leading up to that point, for the last three or four weeks, had not been effective.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Let's continue with what we're doing. At that point, I realized I was still at about four or five BPS in web grid terms, compared to my previous 7.5. However, I knew that if we kept this up, I could get back there. Then they provided me with the dwell cursor, which wasn't ideal at first, but it offered a path forward for continued use and support. I embraced it and never looked back. I'm the kind of person who rolls with the punches. 

So, what was the process and feedback loop for figuring out how to do spike detection effectively for Noah? That's a great question. Let me elaborate.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The update worked by essentially upgrading the software of the implant, similar to how you would update a Tesla or an iPhone. This firmware change enabled us to record averages of populations of neurons near individual electrodes. While we have less resolution regarding which specific neuron is doing what, we gain a broader understanding of the overall activity near an electrode. The feedback was immediate; when we flipped the switch, we observed three or four bits per second right out of the box. That was a lightbulb moment, confirming that we were on the right path. From there, we received a lot of feedback.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
To make this tool useful for independent use, we focused on enabling users to operate it without constant involvement from us. This required re-engineering the user experience, including the dwell cursor, to facilitate independent usage. This is just the beginning of our journey. We hope to return to a point where users can perform multiple clicks and control applications more fluidly and naturally. Most importantly, we aim to improve the web grid number.

Regarding the hover click feature, do you find yourself accidentally clicking on things?

text:
Sometimes I wonder how hard it is to avoid accidentally clicking. I have to continuously keep it moving. To prevent it from reaching that threshold, I keep it moving at a certain speed, constantly doing circles on the screen or moving it back and forth. 

I actually noticed a couple of weeks ago that when I wasn't using the implant, I was still moving my hand back and forth or in circles as if I were trying to keep the cursor from clicking. I was doing this while trying to go to sleep, and I realized it was becoming a habit.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
To avoid the clicking issue, does that create problems when you're gaming? For example, in chess, I've lost several games because I accidentally clicked something. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I think a lot of my experience comes from using the app day in and day out. I often ask the team to implement specific features or changes based on my needs. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
I show them what works, what doesn't work, and what I would like to improve. They take that feedback and usually create amazing solutions that I would have never imagined. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I have many questions about the things I want to do, and they are always present, which is really nice. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Having a Neuralink implant has given me a sense of freedom in how I interact with the world. For people in my position, independence is crucial. The more I can manage on my own, the better. If I can engage with the world without relying on my family or friends for assistance, that's a significant improvement. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Having the freedom to use it whenever I want, without having to wait for others, really takes a load off all of us. I can't thank Nurlink enough for this, and my family feels the same way. Being able to do things on my own at any hour of the day or night means the world to me. 

When I'm up at 2 a.m. playing Web Grid by myself, I imagine the darkness around me with just a light glowing. In those moments, I often find myself in a state of flow, where my mind feels empty and focused.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I usually play music while working, and I have a massive playlist that I enjoy. However, it's also a race against time because I'm constantly checking the battery percentage on my implant. When the battery is above 50%, I feel okay, but as it drops to 30% and then 20%, I start to worry. At 10%, a notification will pop up, which can really disrupt my workflow.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The low battery popup comes up, and I know it’s going to interfere with my progress. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Once I'm in Web Grid, you better break this record, or you're going to waste five hours of your life. It's just fun! Have you ever tried Web Grid with two or three targets? Can you get higher BPS with that? 

Are you referring to different colored targets or multiple targets? Yes, multiple targets can change the outcome. BPS is calculated as the number of correct targets minus incorrect targets, divided by time. So, you can think of different clicks as essentially doubling the number of active targets. The higher the BPS, the more options there are, making the task more difficult.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
It covers the whole screen with a grid, and I don't know what else to say. That's insane! He doesn't like it because it didn't show BPS. I had them put a giant BPS in the background, so now it's the opposite of Zen mode—it's like super hard mode, or "metal mode," with a giant number in the back. We should definitely name it "metal mode." 

You also play Civilization VI? I love Civ VI! I usually go with Korea. The great part about Korea is that they focus on science and tech victories, which was not planned. I've been playing Korea for years, and then all the nerfing stuff happened, so it kind of aligns.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: What I've noticed with tech victories is that if you can rush science early on, you can achieve anything. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
I was focused solely on science and technology, trying to unlock every tech in the tech tree. Then, I accidentally won through a diplomatic victory, and I was so frustrated. I usually focus on reaching a certain military unit and position them around my borders to keep others out. This allows me to build up in a very isolationist manner, concentrating on science and technology.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
It's so much fun! I also saw the Civilization 7 trailer—oh man, I'm so pumped! That's probably coming out next year. Come on, S7, hit me up; I'll alpha or beta test, whatever you need.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: It would be amazing to control an Optimus robot. The link app seems to be getting more refined, and we've made significant progress in terms of what I want from it. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
I want an advanced mode, similar to the menus that usually have a basic mode. I'm one of those power users who wants as much control as possible. That's really all I can ask for—just give me everything. 

Has speech been useful while using it? I mean, do you use speech-to-text, or do you type? There's also a virtual keyboard. I would like to work more on finding a different way to type or text. Right now, I primarily use dictation and the virtual keyboard.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: We've experimented with finger spelling, similar to sign language, and it seems really promising. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Right now, it's finger spelling of the sign language alphabet. If it can pick that up, it should be able to understand the entire sign language. What was the process of training yourself to go from attempted movement to imagined movement? How long did that take? It took a couple of weeks.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
Before, it just happened upon me, but now that I know it's possible, I think I could make it happen with other things. I believe it would be much simpler. Would you get an upgraded implant device? 

Sure, absolutely, whenever they'll let me. So, you don't have any concerns about the surgery or your experience?

You just keep getting upgrades? 

Yeah, I mean, why not? I've seen how much it's impacted my life already, and I know that everything from here on out is just going to get better and better. So, I would love to get the upgrade. 

What future capabilities are you excited about, beyond telepathy? 

Vision is interesting.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: There are fascinating advancements being made for individuals who are blind, enabling them to see, as well as for those with speech impairments. The potential for these technologies is remarkable. For instance, the ability to give someone sight for the first time in their life could be more amazing than helping someone like me. podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: It would be very cool if we could solve issues related to speech, as well as various disabilities that originate in the brain. Nonetheless, there is a lot of potential in addressing brain-related issues.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I am excited about the potential to physically make changes that can help improve people's lives. I believe many of these advancements can be implemented within my lifetime, assuming I live a long life. You mentioned issues like depression, where people could potentially receive help that quickly transforms their mood. Joe has discussed this in terms of wanting to experience what a drug trip feels like, such as being on mushrooms or DMT, suggesting that we could simply flip a switch in the brain. My friend Bane has also talked about similar concepts.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Imagine being able to wipe parts of your memory and re-experience things, like your favorite movie or book, as if for the first time. I mentioned that I’m unsure about the idea of people being able to erase parts of your memory; it seems a bit sketchy to me. He responded that they’re already doing it, so it sounds legitimate. Personally, I would love a high-resolution replay of all my memories. However, I once saw an episode of Black Mirror about that concept, and I don’t think I want it. Black Mirror often presents the worst-case scenarios, which is important, but I think people overlook the best-case or average scenarios too often.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
I don't know what it is about us humans; we tend to focus on the worst possible outcomes. We love drama. It's like we ask, "How is this new technology going to kill everybody?" We just can't help it. Hopefully, people won't dwell on that too much with me, as it could ruin a lot of my plans. 

I assume you're going to take over the world! I love your Twitter. You tweeted, "I'd like to make jokes about hearing voices in my head since getting the Neuralink, but I feel like people would take it the wrong way. Plus, the voices in my head told me not to." Please never stop! 

So, you're talking about Optimus. Is that something you would love to control, the robotic arm or the entirety of Optimus?

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Absolutely, I think there's something fundamentally different about being able to physically interact with the world. For example, the ability to give people sensations through brain interfaces, like Neuralink, could potentially be translated through an Optimus robot as well. There's a fascinating interplay between these technologies. As you mentioned, physically interacting is crucial; 99% of the things I can't do myself require a caretaker to assist me. If an Optimus robot could perform those tasks, it would be incredibly beneficial.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I could live an incredibly independent life and not be a burden on those around me. This would change the way people like me live, at least until whatever this is gets cured. Being able to interact with the world physically would be amazing. It's not just about having a caretaker; it's about simple things, like being able to read a book. Imagine an Optimus robot holding a book open in front of me, allowing me to experience that smell again. I might not be able to feel it at that point, or maybe I could regain some sensation. There's something fundamentally different about reading a physical book compared to staring at a screen or listening to an audiobook.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I actually don't like audiobooks. I've listened to a ton of them, but I would much rather read a physical copy. One of the things I love is opening a book, bringing it up to me, and feeling the touch of the paper. The touch and smell of a book are just special. There's something about the words on the page that can't be replicated, even though they've tried to mimic the page color on devices like the Kindle. It's just not the same. So, one of the things I miss is the tactile experience. I do miss that a lot, especially with many physical things I interact with in the world, like clothes or any other tangible items.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text:
People around me often come and rub things on my face or lay something on me so I can feel the weight. They might rub a shirt on me so I can feel the fabric. There’s something very profound about touch, and it’s something I miss a lot. I would love to experience it again, but we’ll see. 

What would be the first thing you would do with a hand that can touch? 

Give my mom a hug. After that, right? 

Yes, that’s one thing I’ve asked God for every day since my accident: the ability to move, even just my hand, so I could squeeze my mom’s hand and show her how much I care.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: I care deeply for her and love her. Along those lines, I enjoy interacting with the people around me—handshakes, hugs, and simple gestures. However, I worry that if I indulge too much, I might gain weight, which would be unfortunate. I also want to beat Bliss at chess on a physical board. There are so many upsides to these interactions. I want to find ways to connect with Bliss and bring him down to my level because he is such an amazing person, and everything about him is exceptional. Anything I can do to humble him a bit, I'm happy to do. As he's sitting next to me, did you ever make sense of why God puts good people in challenging situations?

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: People go through such hardship, and I think it's all about understanding how much we need God. I don't believe there's any light without the dark. If we were all happy all the time, there would be no reason to turn to God, and the concepts of good and bad would lose their meaning. The darkness and evil in the world help us appreciate the good and the things we have much more. When I had my accident, one of the first things I said to one of my best friends, within the first month or two after it, was...

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: The accident has made me understand and believe that God is real. My interactions with Him have been genuine and worthwhile. In contrast, someone else believes that this experience proves there isn't a God. I see it differently; I believe it is a way for God to test us, build our character, and guide us through trials and tribulations. These challenges help us appreciate how precious He is, the gifts He has given us, and the time we have. Ultimately, I hope we can grow from these experiences, as that is a significant part of our journey here.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: It's not just about having an easy life and doing everything that's simple; it's about stepping out of our comfort zones and truly challenging ourselves. I believe that's how we grow. What gives me hope about our civilization is the people. Even during my few months at Neuralink, looking people in the eyes and hearing their motivations has been incredibly inspiring. They could be in cushier jobs elsewhere, doing things that don't mean much, but instead, they're here because they want to better humanity.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: People around them, those they've interacted with in their lives, want to create better lives for their family members who might have disabilities. They see someone like me and think, "I can do something about that," and they take action. I've always connected most with people; I'm a people person. I love learning about others, their development, and their backgrounds. It's inspiring to see how much people are willing to do for someone like me, even when they don't have to. Their efforts to improve my life give me a lot of hope for humanity, showing how much we care and what we are capable of when we come together.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: We come together to make a difference, despite the bad in the world, which has always existed and always will. This reflects human resilience and our ability to endure. It highlights our desire to help each other and the satisfaction we derive from it. I believe one of our purposes is to support one another. This realization gives me hope—knowing there are still people who care and want to help. Thank you for being one of those individuals and for continuing to inspire others through everything you've faced.

text:
Many people, including myself, have various reasons for appreciating your epic performance on Web Grid. I will be training all night to catch up. I believe in you, and once you return, I know you can beat Bliss. Absolutely, I'm rooting for you—the whole world is rooting for you. Thank you for everything you've done. 

Thanks for listening to this conversation with Nolan Arbaugh, and before that, with Elon Musk, DJ Sa, Matthew McDougall, and Bliss Chapman. To support this podcast, please check out our sponsors in the description. Now, let me leave you with some words from Aldous Huxley in "The Doors of Perception."

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
text: Perception: we live together, we act on and react to one another, but always, in all circumstances, we are by ourselves. The martyrs go hand in hand into the arena, but they are crucified alone. Embracing lovers desperately try to fuse their insulated ecstasies into a single self, seeking transcendence in vain. By its very nature, every embodied spirit is doomed to suffer and enjoy its solitude. Sensations, feelings, insights, and fancies are all private and, except through symbols, incommunicable. We can share information about experiences, but never the experiences themselves. From family to nation, every human group is a society of island universes. Thank you for listening.

podcast_name: Elon Musk: Neuralink and the Future of Humanity | Lex Fridman Podcast
